results.title: The Curse = Xala
results.creator_credit: Ousmane Sembene, Paulin Soumanou Vieyra, Film Domirev and Societe Nationale Cinematographique
results.brief_description: Things are not looking good for rich self-made businessman El Hadj Abdoukader Beye in his third marriage. For starters, there is a huge age difference between him and his wife, whose younger than El Hadj’s daughter. Secondly, he is stricken by a xala, a curse which renders him impotent, on his wedding night. It is through his attempts to cure his condition that writer-director Sembene Ousmane conveys a vivid and satirical image of life in post independence Senegal, and the gap between rich and poor and modernity and tradition. Included as part of Africa95, a nationwide season of the arts of Africa, screened throughout the United Kingdom in 1995. In Wolof and French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Dangerous stranger
results.creator_credit: Sid Davis and Sid Davis Productions
results.brief_description: Produced with the co-operation of Inglewood Police Department and Inglewood Unified School District. Designed to impress children with the need to be on guard against molesters. Dramatises places and circumstances under which the child may encounter dangerous stragers under unsupervised conditions and indicates how to avois potential molesters. Human interest, common sense and humour are used, but fear is scrupulously avoided. (Suitable for elementary grades)

results.title: The Culture explosion
results.creator_credit: Eric Koch and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A discussion of the position of the arts in the 1960’s, particularly in the U.S.A. and Canada. Speakers such as Jonathan Miller, Peter Ustinov, Elke Sommer and Jean Renoir consider various viewpoints such as artistic standards and values (art as an antidote for the drabness of standardised modern life), popular taste and interest(as a response to the ancient urge to create something of beauty), the business side, patronage and government support, and the place of art in society (the essence of art as being sensual and intuitive and beyond the reach of any “culture explosion”).

results.title: The Cry of the gull
results.creator_credit: David Fulton, Gloria Montero, Montero-Fulton Productions and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The health and vitality of the gull reflect the “health” of the Great Lakes. When the gull population diminishes, biologists hasten to discover the reasons. The herring gull on Lake Ontario is in trouble, and so is the water. This film sounds a warning about the pollutants that are being pumped into these waters daily.

results.title: The Crow road
results.creator_credit: Calvin Miller, Bradley Adams, British Broadcasting Corporation and Union Pictures Productions
results.brief_description: Rory McHoan was last seen on his way to visit his brother, Kenneth, seven years ago. No trace of him was ever found despite an exhaustive police investigation. Inspired by his grandmother, Rory’s nephew, Prentice, takes on the task of finding Rory, and uncovering the truth about his missing uncle’s disappearance. With only Rory’s archaic and unreadable computer disks, pages of a novel-in-progress, and a ghost at his shoulders, Prentice must make a long journey with discoveries to be made about himself before he can unravel the dark secrets that lie buried in his family’s history. Based on a novel by Iain Banks. Cast includes: Joseph McFadden, Bill Paterson and Valerie Edmond.

results.title: The Creative stitch
results.creator_credit: Jack Joynes and Creative Embroidery Association
results.brief_description: With so many techniques to explore, a wide variety of materials to be used and so many stitches to be devised, embroidery can be an expressive language. Ideas from nature and painting an be transferred to string embroidery, machine embroidery and other methods of needle weaving.

results.title: The Monsoon frog
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Dreamtime story”.
A young boy, learning to hunt is told never to harm the green frog. In answer to his question why, he is told the story of a young boy of the Dreamtime who had no respect for nature. When the monsoon did not come one year he threatened to kill the green frog, bringer of the monsoon, if she did not send the rain. In revenge she sent her children, thunder and lightning to kill him, but he meets with Tiddalik the giant frog, which causes further complications … Narrated by Belzah Lowah.

results.title: Pariki and the flying foxes
results.creator_credit: Robin James and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Dreamtime story”.
Belzah Lowah narrates this story of the Dreamtime, based on a retelling by Charles P. Mountford. The story is of Pariki, a young boy, one of the first people, who lived on an island. Although he had many animal friends he was lonely, and so, when one day he found himself in an unexplored part of the island, he ventured deep into the forest in spite of the warnings of the rock python. Here he met the evil bat spirit, whose bats caught him and carried him up into the heavens where they became stars and Pariki became the biggest star of all, with the bat spirit becoming the man in the moon.

results.title: The Creation
results.creator_credit: Peter Cooke, Robin James and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Dreamtime story”.
In this imaginative interpretation of an Aboriginal creation myth, the spirits, Baime and Yhi breathe life into the planet Earth, creating plants and animals. However the animals quarrel, causing the Earth to split, releasing the evil spirit Marmoo, who destroys Baime and Yhi’s creation with fire. Baime punishes Marmoo by turning him into a snake. New forests grow from surviving seeds and the animals return but without Baime’s spirit, which he now breathes into his last creations, Man and Woman. Narrated by Bill Lowah.
